Author
[[Radio programming|Radio Show Host]] | years_active = | employer = | organization = American Alliance of Jews and Christians, Toward Tradition | known_for = | notable_works = | net_worth = | awards = | website = http://www.rabbidaniellapin.com | footnotes = | box_width = }} '''Daniel Lapin''' (born January 1, 1947) is a South African-born American [[Orthodox Judaism|Orthodox]] [[rabbi]], author, and public speaker who heads the "American Alliance of Jews and Christians".{{cite web | url= | author=Examiner staff | title=Rabbi Lapin Reveals Prosperity Secrets | date=March 29, 2012 }} {{cite web |url=http://www |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-05-24 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060326070849/http://www/ |archivedate=March 26, 2006 |df=mdy }}[.]examiner[.]com/article/rabbi-lapin-reveals-prosperity-secrets (URL blocked by Wikipedia) He was previously the founding rabbi of the [[Pacific Jewish Center]] in [[Venice, California]],{{cite web|last=Talk Radio Network |title=Rabbi Daniel Lapin Discusses Whether Netanyahu Will Press The White House Hard on Iran |url=http://www.trn1.com/rabbi-daniel-lapin-discusses-whether-netanyahu-will-press-the-white-house-h |accessdate=June 15, 2012 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120511095452/http://www.trn1.com/rabbi-daniel-lapin-discusses-whether-netanyahu-will-press-the-white-house-h |archivedate=May 11, 2012 |df=mdy }} and the former head of Toward Tradition, the Commonwealth Loan Company and the Cascadia Business Institute. Lapin currently hosts a daily television program with his wife, Susan, and provides spiritual advice to people through his website.{{ cite web | last=World Mag | title=Deuteronomy Duo | url=http://www.worldmag.com/archives/1997-02-15 |accessdate = June 26, 2012}} {{subscription required}} == Early life and education == Lapin was born on January 1, 1947, in [[Johannesburg]], South Africa,{{cite web|last=Jewish News of Greater Phoenix |title=Forgiving New Jewish Ties |url=http://www.jewishaz.com/jewishnews/971114/safrica.shtml |accessdate=June 15, 2012 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120610071033/http://www.jewishaz.com/jewishnews/971114/safrica.shtml |archivedate=June 10, 2012 |df=mdy }} to a family of [[Lithuanian Jews|Lithuanian Jewish descents]]. He was the eldest of four siblings.{{Cite book|last=Formicola|first=Jo Renee|title=Religious Leaders and Faith-based Politics: Ten Profiles|last2=Morken|first2=Hubert|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|year=2001|isbn=0847699633|location=|pages=98}} His father, A. H. Lapin, was the nephew of [[Elyah Lopian|Rabbi Elya Lopian]] (1872â€“1970), and served as a prominent and outspoken [[Orthodox Judaism|Orthodox]] rabbi in Johannesburg and [[Cape Town]]. His father eventually established an Orthodox synagogue (''Am Echad'') in [[San Jose, California]], after leaving South Africa in the 1970s. Lapin [[emigration|emigrated]] with his family from South Africa to the United States in the 1970s, and became a [[Naturalization|naturalized]] United States citizen in 1973.{{cite web|last=The Interim |title=Q and A with: Rabbi Daniel Lapin |url=http://www.theinterim.com/2006/oct/14QandA.html |accessdate=June 15, 2012 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150104190534/http://www.theinterim.com/2006/oct/14QandA.html |archivedate=January 4, 2015 |df=mdy }} Prior to coming to the United States, he studied in [[Yeshiva College of South Africa|Yeshivas]] in [[Gateshead]] and [[Jerusalem]]. Lapin has rabbinic ordination from three institutions: Gateshead Yeshiva (1969); Yeshiva Knesset Hezekiah in Israel (1972); and from Rabbi Jacob Ruderman in Baltimore, Maryland (1975). While in his early twenties he returned to South Africa and taught physics and Bible in [[Yeshiva College of South Africa]]. In order to finance his planned move to Israel, Lapin formed a company, "Lapin Marine Enterprises" to manufacture boats. When he made enough money to finance his plans, he sold the company and went to New York in 1973, planning to stay one month in the US and then move to Israel. Lapin had a change of heart, and instead of moving to Israel, he partnered with [[Matis Weinberg|Rabbi Matis Weinberg]], the son of a prominent rabbi in Baltimore, and started a yeshiva for high school and post-high school students in California, Kerem College, in [[Santa Clara, California|Santa Clara]], in 1976. His family re-located to Washington State in 1991 to develop Toward Tradition, and to host a nationally syndicated weekly radio show.{{cite web | last=Catholic Education Resource Center | title=A Rabbi's Warning To U.S. Christians | url=http://catholiceducation.org/articles/persecution/pch0135.htm |accessdate = June 15, 2012}} Lapin has two brothers, [[David Lapin|David]] and [[Raphael Lapin|Raphael]], who are also Orthodox rabbis and have similar educational backgrounds. His sister is married to an American rabbi. Lapin's wife and business partner, Susan Lapin, is also an author and lecturer.{{cite web | last=Jewish World Reviews | title=Opening The Book on Hate | url=http://www.jewishworldreview.com/1100/closing.book.html |accessdate = June 15, 2012}} == Professional career == === Pacific Jewish Center === From 1976 until 1991 Lapin was the rabbi of the Pacific Jewish Center in Venice, California. During those years Lapin and [[Michael Medved]] helped to revitalize the synagogue, which viewed itself as functioning as part of the recent [[Baal teshuva]] movement.{{cite web |last=Pacific Jewish Center |title=About Us |url=http://www.pjcenter.com/aboutus.htm |accessdate=June 15, 2012 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120614022731/http://www.pjcenter.com/aboutus.htm |archivedate=June 14, 2012 |df=mdy }} The Center is known for its outreach to unaffiliated and disconnected Jews, and the Shul remains the last of the synagogues built in Venice during the first part of the 20th century.Prayer Shawls, Flip-Flops Mingle at 'Shul on the Beach', by Rebecca Spence, Forward, September 26, 2007 [http://www.forward.com/articles/11708/]Religion and Prime Time Television By Michael Suman, UCLA Center for Communication Policy, Greenwood Publishing Group, 1997, p. 116 Due to its location in an eclectic neighborhood, worshippers who identify themselves from many different denominations are all welcomed, and attend services and other events. Actors [[Barbra Streisand]]Wenig, Gaby (July 3, 2003) [http://www.jewishjournal.com/community/article/new_rabbi_hopes_more_families_enjoy_sun_surf_shabbat_at_pjc_20030704 New Rabbi Hopes More Families Enjoy Sun, Surf, and Shabbat at PFC] "Jewish Journal of Los Angeles". ''Jewish Journal '' Retrieved 2009-12-22 and [[Richard Dreyfuss]] participated in the religious community and synagogue. === Broadcasting and television === In 1995, Lapin began to broadcast a weekly radio talk show on [[KVI]] in Seattle.{{cite news | last=The Seattle Times | title=Film Critic Michael Medved Will Likely Get KVI Talk Slot | url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19960625&slug=2336194 |accessdate = June 15, 2012 | date=June 25, 1996}}Green, Norman (July 27, 1996) [http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19960727&slug=2341147 Hot Talk' Radio Rabbi Sees Role For The Right â€“ Conservatism Unites Faiths, Says Daniel Lapin.], ''The Seattle Times'' Retrieved 2009-12-22 The show ended in 2006 when he began hosting a Sunday afternoon radio show on [[KSFO]] in San Francisco.{{cite web|last=KSFO 560 Hot Talk |title=Rabbi Daniel Lapin |url=http://www.ksfo.com/showdj.asp?DJID=32341 |accessdate=June 15, 2012 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120505055308/http://ksfo.com/showdj.asp?DJID=32341 |archivedate=May 5, 2012 |df=mdy }} He is frequently interviewed on the ''[[Mike Gallagher (political commentator)|Mike Gallagher]] Show'', the ''[[Michael Medved]] Show'', and the [[David Barton (author)|Wallbuilders]] radio show. Lapin and his wife, Susan Lapin, also appear in the daily television program "Ancient Jewish Wisdom with Rabbi Daniel Lapin" produced by the [[Tri-State Christian Television|TCT Television Network]].{{cite web |last=Truth Tellers |title=Rabbi Lapin: Christians Under Relentless Attack By Secular Judaism |url=http://www.truthtellers.org/alerts/rabbilapin.html |accessdate=June 15, 2012 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120630102018/http://www.truthtellers.org/alerts/rabbilapin.html |archivedate=June 30, 2012 |df=mdy }} Lapin has also been a frequent guest of [[Dave Ramsey]] on ''[[The Dave Ramsey Show (TV program)|The Dave Ramsey Show]]'' on radio and television{{cite web | last=A Real Change | title=Dave Ramsey & Rabbi Daniel Lapin Speak About Dale Carnegie | url=http://www.arealchange.com/blog/dave-ramsey-rabbi-daniel-lapin-speak-dale-carnegie-making-money-honor-relationship-wealth-creation |accessdate = June 16, 2012}} (Link Includes Embedded Video) and on the ''[[Glenn Beck Program]]'' on [[Fox News Channel]] and [[TheBlaze]]. === Lifecodex Publishing Company === Lapin is the founder of the Lifecodex Publishing Company, which is a Web site that handles the sale of his publications and markets his services as a lecturer to businesses, church groups, and other conservative organizations.{{cite web | last=Hebrew Heritage Ministries International | title=Holy Warrior | url=http://www.hebroots.org/hebrootsarchive/0005/000508_h.html |accessdate = June 16, 2012}} Lapin's site has over 40,000 subscribers that he provides with a weekly e-mail containing his teachings and spiritual advice. The site also has archived [[podcast]]s from his show on KSFO, as well as links to numerous television appearances that he has made. The site also contains a section where people can purchase his books, CDs, and DVD.{{cite web | last=RabbiDanielLapin | title=RabbiDanielLapin | url=http://www.rabbidaniellapin.com/ |accessdate = June 15, 2012}}{{cite web | last=Dr. James Dobson Radio Broadcasts | title=The Battle For Civilization â€“ I | url=http://www.drjamesdobson.org/Broadcasts/Broadcast?i=417f5f07-6fba-4bd6-95b5-6161703bb793/ |accessdate = June 15, 2012}} == Publications and lectures == In addition to many books that he has written, Lapin has lectured throughout the United States at different synagogues, businesses, and charities. He has also been quoted by many authors, including [[D. James Kennedy|Dr. James Kennedy]] in "How Would Jesus Vote",{{cite web | last=Dr. James Kennedy & Jerry Newcombe |title=How Would Jesus Vote | url=https://www.amazon.com/How-Would-Jesus-Vote-Perspective/dp/B003D7JZQW/ref=sr_ | accessdate = June 15, 2012}} (Retrieved from "look inside" through Amzaon.com) and by Joseph A. D'Agostino in the National Conservative Weekly Newsletter.{{cite web|last=Human Events Online â€“ The National Conservative Weekly Newsletter |title=Conservative Spotlight: Rabbi Daniel Lapin |url=http://www.humaneventsonline.com/article.php?id=2925 |accessdate=June 15, 2012 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060219151540/http://www.humaneventsonline.com/article.php?id=2925 |archivedate=February 19, 2006 |df=mdy }} Lapin has also spoken for the Heritage Foundation{{cite web | last=Policy Archive | title=The Severed Flower: Conservatism Without God | url=http://www.policyarchive.org/handle/10207/bitstreams/12677.pdf | accessdate = June 16, 2012}} and at the 1996 Republican National Convention. === Lectures and speeches === Lapin has given lectures and public speeches to hundreds of companies and organizations, and continues to do so at locations throughout the United States.{{cite web | last=Daniel Lapin | title=Appearances | url=http://www.rabbidaniellapin.com/speaking_engagements.php | accessdate=June 15, 2012 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120525071052/https://www.rabbidaniellapin.com/speaking_engagements.php | archive-date=May 25, 2012 | url-status=dead }} Some of his most notable speeches include addressing the [[Young America's Foundation]] at their Fifth Annual High School Conference at the [[Rancho del Cielo|Reagan Ranch]] Center in 2011,{{cite web | last=Libertas | title=High School Students Energized by Freedom, Free Markets, and Reagan | url=http://issuu.com/young.americas.foundation/docs/libertas32.2/search?q=Lapin |accessdate = June 15, 2012}} (Retrieved from Issuu.com) the [[1996 Republican National Convention]],{{cite web | last=First Principles |title=Higher Education and the Liberal Arts | url=http://www.firstprinciplesjournal.com/articles.aspx?article=865&theme=hiedu&loc=b | accessdate = June 15, 2012}} and the Congressional Bi-Partisan reception for the 106th Congress in 1999. He has given speeches and lectures for organizations and companies, including the [[Christian Coalition of America|Christian Coalition]], [[Crystal Cathedral]], [[Harvard Law School]], the [[The Heritage Foundation|Heritage Foundation]], [[Christians United for Israel|Voices United for Israel]], and the [[Young Presidents' Jewish liberalism === {{BLP unsourced section|date=September 2014}} Lapin promotes conservative political principles, intermixed with traditional religious observance. Lapin was one of the Jewish voices in support of [[Mel Gibson]]'s controversial film ''[[The Passion of the Christ]]'', and was a strong supporter of the efforts by [[Terri Schiavo case|Terri Schiavo]]'s parents to keep their daughter alive. He is also a strong supporter of [[Pope Pius XII]] as a [[Righteous Among the Nations|righteous gentile]], a term he believes should be renamed "righteous Christian". Lapin has called the United States the most "Jewish-friendly" state in history because of its Christian heritage. He argues that it is better for Jews to promote shared [[Judeo-Christian]] values with the majority than promote solely Jewish values. He has also called [[secular liberalism]] a danger to Judeo-Christian values, and claimed that the [[United States Holocaust Memorial Museum|Holocaust Memorial Museum]] presents [[Anti-Christian sentiment|anti-Christian]] propaganda; he says that the museum ignores, for example, the work of [[Corrie ten Boom]]'s family in unconditionally saving Jews during [[World War II]]. Lapin has declared that the [[Anti-Defamation League]] and its allies are "dangerous organizations that are driving a wedge between [[American Jews]] and Christians". Referring to ADL national director [[Abraham Foxman]], Lapin claimed that by calling ''[[The Passion of the Christ]]'' [[Antisemitism|anti-Semitic]], "what he is saying is that the only way (for Christians) to escape the wrath of Foxman is to repudiate (their own) faith". Lapin also rejects the idea that the [[Jewish left]] represents Judaism. He has excoriated Jewish liberals for their promotion of ideas he views as contrary to traditional Judaism, such as abortion, same-sex marriage, and socialism. He argues that Jewish-born liberals have redefined "Judaism" to mean "liberalism" - and redefined "anti-liberalism" as "anti-Semitism". Lapin has said: "It is time for us to recognize the charge of anti-Semitism for what it often is: a political weapon intended to silence critics of liberalism." === Public celebration of Christmas === Lapin has spoken against the [[Christmas controversy|secularization of Christmas]], saying that, "We see obsequious regard for faiths like Judaism and even [[Islam]], while Christianity is treated with contempt". He is opposed to replacing the "Merry Christmas" greeting with "Happy Holidays", saying, "Let us all go out of our way to wish our many wonderful Christian friends a very merry Christmas ... Nationwide, Christmas [[Nativity scene]]s are banned from city halls and shopping malls, but [[Hanukkah|Chanukah]] menorahs are permitted."Lapin, Daniel (November 24, 2005) [http://www.orthodoxytoday.org/articles5/LapinChristmas.php Merry Christmas is Not Offensive â€“ Jews Should Protect Religious Freedom for Everyone.] ''Orthodoxy Today '' Retrieved 2009-12-22 === Wealth === Lapin asks: "Does God want people to be rich?" ... "Yes!", he says, because God "wants us to be obsessively preoccupied by one another's needs", a habit that the commerce relationship fosters. "Wealth is a consequence of doing the right thing", he says. He argues that the [[Torah]] supports the [[free market]] and opposes punitive taxation, and wants people to pass on assets to their descendants, rather than being taken by the government by [[inheritance tax]]es. == Awards and recognition == Lapin has received endorsements from Dave Ramsey, [[Ken Hutcherson|Dr. Kenneth L. Hutcherson]], Dr. James Dobson, [[Pat Robertson|Dr. Pat Robertson]], and Zig Ziglar.{{cite web | last=RabbiDanielLapin | title=Endorsements | url=http://www.rabbidaniellapin.com/dynpage.php?id=3 | accessdate=June 18, 2012 | url-status=dead | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090129152054/http://rabbidaniellapin.com/dynpage.php?id=3 | archivedate=January 29, 2009 | df=mdy-all }} In 1998, he was recognized by ''Seattle Magazine'' as one of the "Four Faces of Faith" and featured in an article that included three other religious leaders.{{cite web | last=Seattle Magazine | title=The Four Faces of Faith }} In 2007, he was named by ''Newsweek'' as one of the top 50 rabbis in America.{{cite web | last=Newsweek (retrieved from The Daily Beast) | title=The Top 50 Rabbis in America | url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/newsweek/2007/04/01/the-top-50-rabbis-in-america.html | accessdate = June 16, 2012}} == Links to Jack Abramoff == Lapin has been linked to the scandal of [[Jack Abramoff]] through his organization Toward Tradition. From the early 1990s until 2004, Abramoff was a board member of the organization, which required its board members to contribute at least $10,000 per year to the organization, and served a few terms as Chairman of the Board. Abramoff met his contribution one year by donating $10,000 from the [[Capital Athletic Foundation]], an organization Abramoff controlled. E-mails later surfaced that were alleged to have been sent between Lapin and Abramoff. In these e-mails, Abramoff requests that Lapin create fake awards for [[Talmud]]ic studies to help Abramoff gain admittance to the [[Cosmos Club]] in Washington, D. C. Lapin later released a formal statement denying having given any awards to Abramoff, and stated that he was joking in the e-mails and believed that Abramoff was as well.{{cite news | last=The Seattle Times | title=Abramoff Used Area Foundation As A Conduit For Money | url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/localnews/2002728644_lapin09m.html | accessdate=June 16, 2012 | date=January 9, 2006 | url-status=dead | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120630225805/http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/localnews/2002728644_lapin09m.html | archivedate=June 30, 2012 | df=mdy-all }}Curtius, Mary. [http://articles.latimes.com/2005/jun/25/nation/na-jack25 "A Lobbyist's E-Mail Train of Billing, Status, Charity."] ''The Los Angeles Times''. June 25, 2005 ==Family== Lapin told the interviewer that he "is the oldest child" brother of Rabbi [[David Lapin]] and Rabbi [[Raphael Lapin]]; their sister is [[Rebbetzin]] Judith Chill.{{Cite web|title=Genealogy - Geni - private profile - Genealogy|url=https://www.geni.com/people/private/348994016040011495|website=www.geni.com|access-date=2020-05-05}} Their father was the notable South African Rabbi Avraham Hyam Lapin (1912â€“1991), who was a nephew of Rabbi [[Elyah Lopian]] (1876â€“1970). Lapin married Susan Friedberg on 15 May 1979.
